para.text: // XSharp allows you to not only use the using statement to link to namespaces

text.style: font-family:Consolas; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:italic; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#008000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: // You can also link to a static class and call the methods in this class as if they are functions.

text.style: font-family:Consolas; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:italic; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#008000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: // The functions WriteLine and ReadKey() in the following code are actually resolved as System.Console.WriteLine()

text.style: font-family:Consolas; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:italic; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#008000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: // Finally there is also the BEGIN USING .. END USING construct which controls the lifetime of a variable

text.style: font-family:Consolas; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:italic; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#008000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: // At the end of the block the Variable will be automatically disposed.
